3.learning_goal: Core ML Concepts: In this unit, you’ll frame real problems as machine learning tasks, define features and labels, distinguish ML from rule-based systems, walk through the end-to-end ML workflow from data to prediction, and prepare tabular data (splits, cleaning, encoding, scaling) while avoiding common pitfalls like overfitting and data leakage.

chapters.title: Framing Machine Learning Problems
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to recognize when machine learning is appropriate, choose the right task type, and define data, features, and labels so you can clearly scope a practical ML problem.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: What ML Is (and Isn’t)
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand machine learning in contrast to rule-based systems; Identify problems that are appropriate for ML; Distinguish ML from traditional programming logic

lessons.title: ML Task Types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify the main machine learning task types: classification, regression, and clustering; Understand how these task types relate to supervised learning (classification, regression) and unsupervised learning (clustering); Match real-world problems to the correct ML task and learning type (supervised vs. unsupervised); Understand why choosing the correct task type is a critical step before selecting a model or evaluation metric

lessons.title: Data and Labels
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish labeled vs unlabeled data; Identify input features and target variables; Understand how labels guide supervised learning

lessons.title: Features as Signals
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define features as model inputs; Identify raw vs derived features; Understand why feature quality impacts model performance

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: ML vs Rules in a Smart Home
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice distinguishing where rule-based logic ends and machine learning begins in a smart home scenario. Output: Completed worksheet or notes classifying each smart home behavior as rule-based or ML-based with short justifications.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Task Type Match-Up
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen your ability to match real-world problems to classification, regression, or clustering and to supervised vs unsupervised learning. Output: Filled-in table or quiz sheet where each scenario is labeled with the correct ML task type and learning type.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Features and Labels in a Music App
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify input features and target labels in a music recommendation app and separate labeled from unlabeled data. Output: A feature–label mapping list that clearly marks which columns are features, which are labels, and which are unlabeled in the given scenario.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie Rating Signals
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice turning raw user behavior into features and labels for a movie rating prediction problem. Output: A small, hand-crafted “dataset” table where each row has clearly defined features (signals) and an appropriate label for a rating/like prediction task.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: ML Problem Scoping
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice scoping a realistic ML problem by defining the task type, features, labels, and what success looks like. Output: A short written problem brief for an ML project (e.g., churn prediction) that clearly states task type, example features, label, and evaluation idea.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: From Training to Predictions
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how machine learning models are trained, how they make predictions, and how to describe them as functions that map inputs to outputs. Practice using core ML workflow vocabulary by designing simple classifiers, outlining real-world workflows, and distinguishing training-time learning from prediction-time use.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Training vs Prediction
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe what happens during model training; Understand how trained models make predictions; Identify when a model is “learning” vs “using knowledge”

lessons.title: Models as Functions
lessons.learning_outcomes: Describe a model as a function mapping inputs to outputs; Compare simple rule logic to learned decision boundaries; Understand why models generalize instead of memorizing

lessons.title: ML Workflow Overview
lessons.learning_outcomes: Outline the full ML workflow from data to prediction; Identify where data prep, training, and evaluation fit; Use correct ML vocabulary to describe each step

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Training vs Prediction Timeline
lessons.learning_outcomes: Clarify when a model is learning and when it is just using learned knowledge in a step-by-step story. Output: A labeled timeline or flow diagram that separates training-time activities from prediction-time activities in a concrete scenario.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Models as Functions Quiz
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce the idea of a model as a function mapping inputs to outputs and contrast it with simple if/else rules. Output: Completed quiz or matching exercise where each example is identified as a rule-based system or an ML “function” and explained briefly.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Email Spam Function
lessons.learning_outcomes: Conceptually design an “email spam classifier” as a function by specifying inputs, outputs, and example decision behavior. Output: A pseudo-code or structured description of a function that takes email properties as inputs and outputs “spam” or “not spam”.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: ML Workflow Card Sort
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice ordering and naming the key steps of an ML workflow from raw data to prediction. Output: An ordered list or diagram where each workflow card (data collection, cleaning, splitting, training, evaluation, prediction) is placed in the correct sequence with a one-line description.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Workflow for a Ride Price Predictor
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply ML workflow vocabulary by designing the end-to-end workflow for a ride price prediction system. Output: A written workflow outline with bullet points for each step (data, features, training, evaluation, deployment/prediction) tailored to the ride price example.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Decision Boundary Sketch
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build intuition about learned decision boundaries by sketching how a model might separate two classes in a simple 2D feature space. Output: A hand-drawn or digital plot with sample points and a rough boundary line or region showing how a model might classify new points.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Trustworthy Models with Tabular Data
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to load and inspect tabular datasets, choose features and targets, and perform reliable train/test splits. Build intuition for common ML pitfalls—overfitting, data leakage, and unrealistic expectations—and practice recognizing and avoiding them in simple, real-world-style scenarios.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Common ML Pitfalls
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify data leakage and why it breaks evaluation; Understand overfitting in intuitive terms; Recognize unrealistic performance expectations

lessons.title: Loading Tabular Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Load datasets using pandas; Inspect rows, columns, and data types; Identify feature columns and targets

lessons.title: Train / Test Split
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain why test data must be held out; Split data using scikit-learn; Describe how splits affect evaluation trustworthiness

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Spot the Pitfall
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen your ability to recognize overfitting, data leakage, and unrealistic performance expectations from short case descriptions. Output: A set of annotated case summaries where each is labeled with the main pitfall (or “no pitfall”) and a brief explanation.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe Orders Table Inspection
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice loading and inspecting a small tabular dataset, identifying columns, data types, features, and target. Output: A short report (or notebook cells) showing dataset head, info/summary, and a clear list of which columns are features and which is the target.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Housing Data Overview
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce basic pandas operations by loading a housing-style dataset and exploring its structure and basic statistics. Output: Notebook cells or script output with dataset loading, head(), describe(), info(), and a short written summary of key observations.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Train Test Split for Customer Churn
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply a proper train/test split to a churn dataset and explain how the split supports trustworthy evaluation. Output: Code or pseudo-code that performs a train/test split and prints the shapes of the resulting sets with a short justification of the chosen split ratio.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Evaluating Split Scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build intuition about how different train/test splits affect evaluation reliability and data leakage risk. Output: A comparison table or notes describing multiple split scenarios (e.g., 50/50, 80/20, temporal split) with pros and cons for each.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Overfitting Intuition with Curves
lessons.learning_outcomes: Develop an intuitive feel for overfitting by comparing model behavior on “training-like” vs “new” points in a conceptual curve-fitting example. Output: A sketch or conceptual diagram contrasting a simple underfit, a good fit, and an overfit curve with labeled training and test regions.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Preparing Features for Models
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to clean and transform tabular data for machine learning by handling missing values, encoding categorical variables, and scaling numeric features, and build intuition for how these choices affect different model types.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Handling Missing Values
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify missing data in datasets; Apply simple imputation strategies; Explain tradeoffs of different approaches

lessons.title: Encoding Categories
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify categorical vs numeric features; Encode categorical variables for ML models; Explain why models require numeric inputs

lessons.title: Scaling Numeric Features
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain feature scale and why it matters; Apply basic scaling techniques; Identify models sensitive to feature scale

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Missing Data in Patient Records
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice identifying missing values and choosing simple imputation strategies in a medical records-style table. Output: A marked-up table or notebook cells showing where data is missing, what imputation strategy is chosen for each column, and the resulting filled-in values.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Imputation Strategies Comparison
lessons.learning_outcomes: Compare the effects of different simple imputation methods on numeric and categorical features. Output: A small before/after table (or code output) showing at least two imputation strategies applied to the same columns with a short note on tradeoffs.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Encoding Cafe Menu Categories
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice identifying categorical vs numeric features and apply basic encoding strategies to turn categories into numbers. Output: A transformed version of a small cafe menu/order dataset where categorical columns are encoded (e.g., one-hot or label encoding) and documented.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Encoding Customer Segments
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce encoding concepts by designing an encoding plan for multiple categorical fields with different cardinalities. Output: A written encoding plan plus example encoded table rows showing how each categorical feature will be represented numerically.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Feature Scaling for Fitness Data
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply basic scaling techniques (e.g., standardization or min-max) to numeric fitness-tracking features and inspect the results. Output: A before/after comparison of numeric columns showing scaled values and confirmation that scales are now comparable.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Scale Sensitivity Exploration
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build intuition about which models are sensitive to feature scale and why scaling can change model behavior. Output: A short matrix or notes mapping several model types (e.g., k-NN, linear regression, tree-based models) to whether they are scale-sensitive with brief reasoning.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

4.learning_goal: Supervised & Unsupervised Models: In this unit, you will train and evaluate linear, tree-based, and ensemble models for classification and regression, practice cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning, and explore unsupervised techniques like clustering and PCA to interpret structure in data.

chapters.title: First Steps with Supervised Models
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to train and evaluate basic supervised learning models for classification and regression. Understand key metrics for both tasks, see why accuracy alone is not enough, and practice applying Logistic and Linear Regression to realistic problems.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: First Supervised Model - Logistic Regression
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain binary classification problems; Train a Logistic Regression model end-to-end; Introduce the idea of predicted probabilities vs. predicted classes; Motivate the need for model evaluation (why accuracy alone is not enough)

lessons.title: Classification Metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Calculate and interpret accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score; Read and interpret a confusion matrix; Re-evaluate the Logistic Regression model using different metrics; Discuss how metric choice depends on the problem context

lessons.title: Linear Regression
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain numeric prediction tasks; Train a Linear Regression model; Interpret predictions vs. actual values; Introduce regression error intuitively (distance from the true value)

lessons.title: Regression Metrics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Calculate MAE, MSE/RMSE, and R²; Explain what each metric reveals about model errors; Compare regression models using appropriate metrics

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Spam email classifier
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will train a Logistic Regression model to classify short email snippets as spam or not spam and compare predicted probabilities vs. predicted classes. Output: A script that loads a small text dataset, trains a binary Logistic Regression classifier, and prints predicted class and probability for a few sample emails.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Medical test confusion matrix
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will compute and interpret accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and a confusion matrix for a medical test classifier, and discuss why accuracy alone can be misleading. Output: A script that trains a binary classifier, prints the confusion matrix and multiple metrics, and highlights metric values in a short textual summary.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Loan approval metric explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will simulate different classification thresholds for a loan approval Logistic Regression model and observe how precision, recall, and F1-score change with the threshold. Output: A script that sweeps over several probability thresholds, computes metrics at each, and prints or plots how precision/recall/F1 vary.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Apartment price regression
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will train a Linear Regression model to predict apartment prices from features like size and number of rooms, and compare predictions to actual prices. Output: A script that fits a Linear Regression model, prints sample predictions vs. true prices, and calculates simple prediction errors.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Regression metric comparison
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will compute MAE, MSE, RMSE, and R² for one or two regression models and interpret what each metric reveals about prediction errors. Output: A script that trains at least one regression model, computes all four metrics, and prints a concise comparison table of their values.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Tree Models, Ensembles, and Overfitting
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to train and compare tree-based models and ensembles, spot overfitting vs. good generalization, and use validation and cross-validation to evaluate model performance in practice.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Tree-Based Models
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain decision trees at a conceptual level; Train a tree-based classifier; Compare linear vs. non-linear models; Discuss strengths and limitations of tree-based approaches

lessons.title: Ensembles
lessons.learning_outcomes: Introduce ensemble methods (Random Forest, Gradient Boosting) at a high level; Explain why ensembles are commonly used in practice; Build intuition for why combining models often improves performance

lessons.title: Overfitting, Generalization & Validation
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify signs of overfitting and underfitting; Compare train vs. test performance; Explain the bias-variance tradeoff; Introduce cross-validation conceptually; Compare single train/test split vs. multiple folds

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie review decision tree
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will train a decision tree classifier to predict whether a movie review is positive or negative and visualize or inspect the learned splits. Output: A script that fits a decision tree on a text or numeric dataset and prints the tree structure or feature importances with example predictions.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Linear vs tree model showdown
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will compare a Logistic Regression model and a decision tree classifier on the same classification dataset and analyze their performance differences. Output: A script that trains both models, evaluates them with at least accuracy and F1-score, and prints a side-by-side metric comparison.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Random forest credit risk
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will train a Random Forest classifier on a credit risk–style dataset and interpret basic feature importances and performance. Output: A script that fits a Random Forest, prints metrics and top feature importances, and shows a few example predictions.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Gradient boosting churn model
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will train a simple Gradient Boosting classifier (e.g., GradientBoostingClassifier or XGBoost/lightGBM if available) to predict customer churn and compare it to a single decision tree. Output: A script that trains both models, evaluates them on a test set, and prints which model performs better under chosen metrics.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Overfitting detector
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will experiment with tree depth and other settings to create underfitting and overfitting scenarios and compare train vs. test performance. Output: A script that trains multiple decision trees with different max_depth values, prints train/test metrics, and highlights where overfitting begins.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cross-validation sampler
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will implement a simple cross-validation workflow with a tree-based model and compare the stability of CV scores to a single train/test split. Output: A script that runs both a single train/test evaluation and k-fold cross-validation, then prints the mean and standard deviation of CV scores vs. the single-split score.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Smarter Validation and Tuning
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to estimate model performance with cross-validation, tune hyperparameters with grid and randomized search, and interpret search results responsibly. Distinguish supervised from unsupervised learning and sketch practical unsupervised projects like customer segmentation.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Cross-Validation Basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain cross-validation conceptually; Use cross-validation to estimate performance; Compare single split vs multiple folds

lessons.title: Hyperparameters and Search
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define hyperparameters vs learned parameters; Use GridSearchCV or RandomizedSearchCV; Interpret tuning results responsibly

lessons.title: Unsupervised Learning
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain how unsupervised learning differs from supervised; Identify use cases without labels; Describe exploratory ML goals

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cross-validation score explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will apply k-fold cross-validation to a supervised model and compare performance estimates for different numbers of folds. Output: A script that runs cross-validation with several k values (e.g., 3, 5, 10) and prints the mean and variance of scores for each.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Grid search hyperparameter tuner
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will use GridSearchCV to tune key hyperparameters of a classifier and interpret the best parameters and scores. Output: A script that defines a small parameter grid, runs GridSearchCV, and prints the best parameter set along with cross-validated performance.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Randomized search speed test
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will use RandomizedSearchCV to explore a wider hyperparameter space and compare its runtime and results to a grid search. Output: A script that runs both GridSearchCV and RandomizedSearchCV with limited settings, then prints timing and best scores for each.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Hyperparameter report generator
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will extract and summarize cross-validation results from a search object into a simple, interpretable ranking of hyperparameter combinations. Output: A script that reads cv_results_ from a search, creates a sorted table of parameter sets with mean and std scores, and prints the top candidates.

lessons.title: Theory Practice Lesson: Supervised vs unsupervised scenarios
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will classify example problem descriptions as supervised or unsupervised learning tasks and explain why labels are or are not required. Output: A short quiz-style exercise (e.g., text prompts and your written answers) that matches scenarios to supervised/unsupervised categories with brief justifications.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Customer segmentation clustering idea board
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will brainstorm and outline an unsupervised learning project for customer segmentation, identifying available features, goals, and evaluation ideas. Output: A written project sketch describing dataset features, why labels are absent, what patterns you hope to discover, and how you might judge usefulness.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Clustering and Dimensionality Reduction
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to group unlabeled data with K-Means, choose a sensible number of clusters, and interpret clustering results. Practice using PCA to reduce high-dimensional data for visualization and combine it with clustering on real datasets.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: K-Means Clustering
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain how K-Means groups data; Train a clustering model; Interpret clusters at a high level

lessons.title: Choosing Number of Clusters
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain the role of k; Use simple heuristics to choose cluster count; Interpret clustering tradeoffs

lessons.title: PCA for Visualization
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain dimensionality reduction intuitively; Apply PCA to reduce features; Visualize high-dimensional data in 2D

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: K-means cafe customers
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will apply K-Means clustering to fictional cafe customer data (e.g., visit frequency and spending) and interpret the resulting customer groups. Output: A script that runs K-Means with a chosen k, assigns cluster labels to customers, and prints basic cluster summaries (centroids and counts).

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: K-means image color palette
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will use K-Means to cluster the colors in an image and create a reduced color palette. Output: A script that loads an image, applies K-Means to its pixel colors, and prints or displays the cluster centroids as the dominant colors.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Elbow method cluster chooser
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will implement the elbow method to explore how inertia changes with different k values and visually choose a reasonable number of clusters. Output: A script that runs K-Means for several k values, records inertia, and produces a simple elbow plot or printed table for inspection.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Silhouette score explorer
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will compute silhouette scores for different numbers of clusters and interpret which k yields better-separated clusters. Output: A script that fits K-Means for multiple k, computes silhouette scores, and prints a comparison table or simple plot.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: PCA digits visualization
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will apply PCA to a high-dimensional dataset (e.g., handwritten digits) to reduce it to 2D and visualize the data points colored by class labels. Output: A script that runs PCA to 2 components and generates a 2D scatter plot of the transformed points with colors indicating true classes.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: PCA plus clustering combo
lessons.learning_outcomes: You will combine PCA for dimensionality reduction with K-Means clustering and compare cluster structure in the reduced 2D space. Output: A script that applies PCA to reduce features, runs K-Means on the reduced data, and plots the 2D PCA representation with points colored by cluster label.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions
